title: Enhancing the economic, health and social capabilities of highly vulnerable youth
abstractText: In sub-Saharan Africa new HIV infections are disproportionately affecting young women.  In South Africa, socially and economically disadvantaged young people, especially females, are at the highest risk for HIV, early pregnancy and parenthood, premature school leaving and severe lack of livelihood opportunities.  With sharp rises in prime-age adult mortality due to AIDS, many already at-risk adolescents face the prospect of falling even further behind socially and economically due to the loss of one or both parents, teachers and other key adults. This project will test a randomized intervention designed to provide vulnerable young people residing in poor, peri-urban HIV/AIDS affected communities with strategies for building economic, social and health skills.  The intervention will be delivered in conjunction with local schools and will target students in grades 10 and 11.  The strategic skills proposed are to help build economic assets and offer protective strategies against HIV and early pregnancy.
